awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Effects of community interactions in scaling of microbial processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Specifically, this research will provide new understanding of how microorganisms in leaf litter (bacteria and fungi in dead leaves and grasses) respond to drought and influence the recycling of carbon from plant materials to the atmosphere. This research is critical for understanding how grasslands may respond under future climate conditions, as feedbacks between global environmental change and ecosystems influence a number of environmental services that disproportionately affect low-income communities. Specifically, feedbacks between grassland ecosystems and drought in Southern California negatively impact air quality and increase fire risk. Additionally, as a part of the training plan, the fellow will contribute to the teaching and mentoring of people from underrepresented groups in academia through organized workshops for community college transfer students. 

The fellow will use experimental and theoretical approaches in order to determine the mechanistic basis of how microbial physiology at the population- and community-scale influences ecosystem function in grasslands. Specifically, the fellow will use laboratory experiments of culturable leaf litter microbes and a trait-based model of microbial dynamics that predicts decomposition from microbial physiology and environmental conditions to test two hypotheses: 1. Observed community-average traits of leaf litter microbes (growth, extracellular enzyme activity, and stress tolerance) are not equal to the average of individuals. 2. Positive non-additive effects are more prevalent under moderate drought scenarios. This fellow will gain training in data generation and data-model integration that will be used to generate generalizable understanding of how microbial communities respond to environmental change and influence ecosystem processes. Additionally, to provide mentoring and research opportunities for students from non-traditional and previously excluded backgrounds in academia, the fellow will organize a 10-week workshop series for community college transfer students. This workshop series is aimed at community college transfer students because increases in the enrollment of Black, Latinx, and other underrepresented communities in higher education are primarily driven by community college enrollment. This program will help to increase student sense of belonging and academic confidence through group mentoring and provide opportunities to become involved in undergraduate research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbial communities--consisting of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses--are an important component of all ecosystems on Earth. Within a microbial community, microbial populations interact with each other in both positive and negative ways. For example, a microbial population may positively influence another population by supplying a food source, an interaction often referred to as cross-feeding. Alternatively, microbial populations may negatively influence each other if they are both competing for the same food source. Understanding how different microbial populations interact is the first step towards mechanistic prediction of how microbial communities drive ecosystem functioning and influence ecosystem responses to climate change.

Dr. Bertolet completed a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (PRFB), in which she explored how interactions within leaf litter microbial communities (bacteria and fungi in deaf leaves and grasses) respond to drought and influence the recycling of carbon from plant material to the atmosphere. Specifically, Dr. Bertolet used a mathematical simulation model of litter decomposition to investigate which traits of microbial populations determined their interactions and how interactions differed under different scenarios of drought. The mathematical modeling approach allowed Dr. Bertolet to generate fine-scale predictions of microbial interactions that cannot be observed in naturally occurring microbial communities with current technologies. Thus, this work demonstrated a new and innovative avenue for researchers to understand how microbial communities may contribute to global environmental change.

During the fellowship period, Dr. Bertolet accomplished her primary research objective of exploring microbial interactions under drought. Specifically, she finds evidence that interactions increase in frequency and intensity with drought stress and tend to positively influence overall decomposition rates due to cross-feeding interactions. That is, communities that are more diverse may be predicted to have higher decomposition because populations are more cooperative in order to lessen the effect of the stress. This work was presented at two international conferences, the Ecological Society of America and the Connection Across Borders - Microbial Ecology Conference. Overall, this work adds to new ecological theory about how microbial communities influence ecosystem carbon cycling dynamics that is necessary to better understand potential climate change scenarios and impacts.

In addition to the scientific progress, work within the project had broader impacts on student mentorship and community engagement and outreach. Dr. Bertolet directly mentored two graduate students and wrote a review of those experiences that was published in the Limnology & Oceanography Bulletin. Additionally, Dr. Bertolet planned and led two workshops with community groups to address community needs for combatting climate change in the Southern California region. The workshops included local land managers, environmental justice groups, academic researchers in biology and social science, and K-12 educators.

Lastly, the training provided by the Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Biology allowed Dr. Bertolet to make significant progress in skill-building as an interdisciplinary scientist, mentor, and teacher. Most notably, Dr. Bertolet advanced her skills in mathematical modeling and bioinformatics, team science collaboration, and mentoring and communication.
